title: DOJ investigative summaries

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DOJ investigative summaries
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Investigative summaries and/or any summary documents pertaining to the DOJ's multiple inquiries into entities that have "misled the public about the long-term side effects of chemical and surgical mutilation under the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act," pursuant to Executive Order 14187, “Protecting Children from Chemical and Surgical Mutilation.”

Under the FOIA Improvement Act of 2016, agencies must adopt a presumption of disclosure, withholding information “only if . . . disclosure would harm an interest protected by an exemption” or “disclosure is prohibited by law.”

The FOIA Improvement Act of 2016 also amended the FOIA as follows (5 USC 552(a)(8)):

(A) An agency shall—
(i) withhold information under this section only if—
(I) the agency reasonably foresees that disclosure would harm an interest protected by an exemption described in subsection (b); or
(II) disclosure is prohibited by law; and
(ii) (I) consider whether partial disclosure of information is possible whenever the agency determines that a full disclosure of a requested record is not possible; and
(II) take reasonable steps necessary to segregate and release nonexempt information. . .

In the event some portions of the requested records are properly exempt from disclosure, please disclose any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions of the requested records. If it is your position that a document contains non-exempt segments, but that those non-exempt segments are so dispersed throughout the document as to make segregation impossible, please state what portion of the document is non-exempt, and how the material is dispersed throughout the document. Claims of nonsegregability must be made with the same degree of detail as required for claims of exemptions in a Vaughn index. If a request is denied in whole, please state specifically that it is not reasonable to segregate portions of the record for release.

Further, “the withholding agency must supply ‘a relatively detailed justification, specifically identifying the reasons why a particular exemption is relevant and correlating those claims with the particular part of a withheld document to which they apply.’”

In addition, I ask that your agency exercise its discretion to release records which may be technically exempt, but where withholding serves no important public interest.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

If a portion of the responsive records become available before the entire request is complete, I respectfully request that the DOJ provide records on a rolling basis.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ileana Garnand

title: Mayday USA Tour (Department of Parks and Recreation)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing in regards to a pair of public demonstrations and protests which occurred in Seattle last week. 
The first event was held in Cal Anderson Park on Saturday, May 24th. A second, followup event was held outside of City Hall on Tuesday, May 27th.
For the purposes of identifying the correct party and records, the event's original registration page can be found here: https://www.maydayusa.co/

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

* Permits and related application materials submitted to (or issued by) your department, including any attachments, maps, or forms, for either of the above events. 
     * If multiple venues were considered, I would like the relevant records for each of them.

* All correspondence (including emails, letters, and internal memos) between:
     * Your department and the organizers or any representatives of these events.
     * Your department and any other city department, specifically in regards to these events.
     * Internal communications within your department that relate to the planning, permitting, or management of these events.

Please include any records dated between January 1st, 2025, and June 1st, 2025.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Elizabeth Haste

title: Commonweath Equity Audity Quarterly Reports

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Commonweath Equity Audity Quarterly Reports
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Copies of all Quarterly reports following the Commonwealth's Equity Audit for the Period July 1, 2021, to Present.

These reports were mandatory as a result of the Barnes and Thornburg Investigation.

According to the  "Quarterly Report 1 - Commonwealth's Equity Audit July 1, 2021 - December 15, 2021"   (Attached):  "VMI began submitting 'quarterly reports' to the BOV for follow-on submission to SCHEV and the
Virginia Military Institute and the General Assembly on 15 December 2021, and will continue this practice for the next three years."

These lawfully required documents must exist and should be readily available.

If VMI discontinued providing these mandatory reports at any time or failed to submit one or more of the required reports I request records showing who in the appropriate position of authority made the decision to stop reporting and the basis for that decision as well as the notificationsto the proper agencies and offices to which these mandatory reports were to be submitted (BOV, GA, SCHEV, etc.) as well as the associated approval to end or otherwise limit this mandatory requirement.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Anonymous.

title: Request for Annex A of HSPD-20 (Continuity of Government Directive) – DHS and FEMA (Department of Homeland Security)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

To Whom It May Concern,

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552), I hereby request a complete and releasable copy of Annex A of Homeland Security Presidential Directive 20 (HSPD-20), issued on May 9, 2007, concerning Continuity of Government (COG) and Continuity of Operations (COOP) planning.

While the primary text of HSPD-20 is publicly available, Annex A remains unpublished despite being publicly described as “unclassified.” This status has been referenced in official statements by federal personnel and in briefings to Congress. Therefore, there is no lawful basis to withhold Annex A under FOIA exemptions for classified material or national security.

This request is directed to both the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) due to their documented custodial and operational responsibilities in national continuity policy and planning.

If Annex A has been reclassified, withheld, superseded, or transferred to another component or agency, please provide:

1) A formal written denial specifying the legal exemption(s) under 5 U.S.C. § 552(b),

2) All segregable non-exempt portions of the document,

3) And any associated metadata, including:

-Title

-Authoring office

-Date of creation

-Classification status

-Dissemination or control markings

-Routing or transfer history (if applicable)

I request this information in digital format, if available, and waive physical duplication unless digital access is impossible.

As this request concerns high public interest in governmental continuity planning, national emergency operations, and constitutional governance, I request a waiver of fees under FOIA's public interest provisions.

Please confirm receipt and provide tracking numbers for each component of this multi-agency request.

In accordance with the statutory time limits in 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6), I expect a response within 20 working days, or notification of any extension due to “unusual circumstances” as defined in the Act.

Thank you for your time, consideration, and compliance with the Freedom of Information Act

Cordially,

Yasmin Mahamed

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Yasmin Mahamed

title: ALPR Audit

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: ALPR Audit
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

1. Organization Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period January 1, 2025, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency.

2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of January 1, 2025, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System.

The audit data may be limited to devices located in or operated by District 8, or devices located in St. Clair, Madison, Monroe, and Jersey counties, if possible.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Scott Kampas

title: ALPR Audit Reports Review by Chief of Police Schenita Stewart

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: ALPR Audit Reports Review by Chief of Police Schenita Stewart
communications.communication:
Subject: ALPR Audit Reports Review by Chief of Police Schenita Stewart

Dear FOIA Officer,

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request records related to the Evanston Police Department’s (EPD) use of Flock Safety automated license plate reader (ALPR) technology. This request is based on a recent communication from Schenita Stewart, Chief of Police regarding state surveillance and Evanston’s Welcoming City Ordinance:

“To ensure compliance with the Welcoming City Ordinance and protect community trust, I have assigned a dedicated supervisor to oversee all aspects of ALPR usage within EPD. Furthermore, we conduct regular organizational and network audits, which I personally review. EPD also operates under a clear and established policy governing ALPR use, reinforcing both accountability and transparency.”

According to the City of Evanston's website page on the "Welcoming City Ordinance" (Ordinance 17-O-25):

"Key updates to the Ordinance include:

Data Protection: Prohibiting the sharing of city databases or information with federal immigration agencies, or with third parties unless they certify against its use for civil immigration enforcement.

Expanded Safeguards: Clarifying that City officials will not participate in civil immigration enforcement by any agency or personnel, including private contractors. The City will continue to comply with a valid criminal warrant.

Closing Loopholes: Strengthening policies to eliminate exceptions that previously allowed limited City involvement in immigration enforcement under certain conditions.

Support for Immigrants: Codifying practices that assist crime victims in obtaining specific visas and providing immigration resource information through public services like 311.

Safe Public Buildings: The City is now tasked with developing policies for its public facilities that prioritize limiting immigration enforcement operations on their premises to the fullest extent allowed by law."

In light of this statement made by Schenita Stewart, Chief of Police, along with the updates to Evanston's Welcoming City Ordinance, and in accordance with Illinois law (625 ILCS 5/2-130), which prohibits sharing automated license plate reader ALPR data with out-of-state agencies for purposes such as interfering with reproductive health access or enforcing immigration laws, I request full transparency for the following:

1) Any records showing review or oversight of Flock Safety automated license plate reader ALPR Organization or Network audit reports by the Chief of Police Schenita Stewart from January 1, 2024, to the present - including emails, memos, meeting notes, audit summaries, annotations, or briefings demonstrating the Stewart’s direct involvement in reviewing audit data.

2) Any communications between the Chief of Police Schenita Stewart and Evanston Police Department supervisors or Flock Safety automated license plate reader ALPR administrators regarding network audit findings that raised questions or concerns, including but not limited to:
    a) Access by out-of-state agencies (e.g., AL, FL, IN, KY, MO, NC, TX, etc) 
    b) Federal agency involvement (e.g., DHS, HSI, ICE, CBP, etc)
    c) References to abortion or reproductive health care (e.g., abortion, women, woman, pregnant, pp, planned parenthood, etc)
    d) References to immigration enforcement (e.g., immigration, border patrol, 287g, etc)
    e) Search reasons lacking case numbers or specific descriptions (e.g., inv, p, m, zz, training, test, ab501, invest, narcotics, drugs, 123abv, etc)

3) Any internal protocols or policies that describe the role of the Evanston Police Department’s chief or supervisors in reviewing Flock Safety automated license plate reader ALPR audits and identifying potentially inappropriate use, particularly regarding compliance with Illinois statutes and Evanston’s Welcoming City Ordinance.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,
Niles Coalition

Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center.

communications.subject: RTKL 0625-25 Interim Response
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Sawyer,

This email acknowledges receipt by the Department of Corrections (the Department) of your written request for records under the Pennsylvania Right-to-Know Law (RTKL). Your request was received on June 2, 2025.

In accordance with the RTKL, you are hereby notified that, for the reason set forth below, the Department is extending the final response date of your request to July 9, 2025.


  *   The extent or nature of the request precludes a response within the required time period.

At this time, the Department is unable to provide you with an estimated cost to fulfill your current request if it is granted.  Any actual or estimated fees will be identified in the Department's future response.

Sincerely,

Yihsien Han
